description.content:
Last Updated July 2025

You can use Oracle REST APIs to view and manage data stored in Oracle Supply Chain Management Cloud.

Whether you're experienced with or new to REST, use this guide to find what you need, including:

  • A quick start that walks you through a simple request example.
  • Detailed descriptions for each REST API resource.

item.name: Get one measure type association for an activity type

request.name: Get one measure type association for an activity type

description.content: When this parameter is provided, the specified children are included in the resource payload (instead of just a link). The value of this query parameter is "all" or "". More than one child can be specified using comma as a separator. Example: ?expand=Employees,Localizations. Nested children can also be provided following the format "Child.NestedChild" (Example: ?expand=Employees.Managers). If a nested child is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?expand=Employees.Managers" is the same as "?expand=Employees,Employees.Managers" (which will expand Employees and Managers).

This parameter filters the resource fields. Only the specified fields are returned, which means that if no fields are specified, no fields are returned (useful to get only the links). If an indirect child resource is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?fields=Employees.Managers:Empname" is the same as "?fields=;Employees:;Employees.Managers:Empname" (which will only return the "Empname" field for Managers). the value of this query parameter is a list of resource fields. The attribute can be a direct (Example: Employees) or indirect (Example: Employees.Managers) child. It cannot be combined with expand query parameter. If both are provided, only fields will be considered.

Format: ?fields=Attribute1,Attribute2

Format for fields in child resource: ?fields=Accessor1:Attribute1,Attribute2
The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:
self,canonical

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

response.name: The following table describes the default response for this task.

request.name: Get all measure type associations for an activity type

More than one child can be specified using comma as a separator. Example: ?expand=Employees,Localizations. Nested children can also be provided following the format "Child.NestedChild" (Example: ?expand=Employees.Managers). For example, "?expand=Employees.Managers" is the same as "?expand=Employees,Employees.Managers" (which will expand Employees and Managers).

This parameter filters the resource fields. Only the specified fields are returned, which means that if no fields are specified, no fields are returned (useful to get only the links). If an indirect child resource is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?fields=Employees.Managers:Empname" is the same as "?fields=;Employees:;Employees.Managers:Empname" (which will only return the "Empname" field for Managers). the value of this query parameter is a list of resource fields. The attribute can be a direct (Example: Employees) or indirect (Example: Employees.Managers) child. It cannot be combined with expand query parameter. Format: ?fields=Attribute1,Attribute2

Format for fields in child resource: ?fields=Accessor1:Attribute1,Attribute2
The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:
self,canonical
This parameter restricts the number of resources returned inside the resource collection. If the limit exceeds the resource count then the framework will only return the available resources.
Used to define the starting position of the resource collection. If offset exceeds the resource count then no resources are returned. Default value is 0.
The resource collection representation will include the "estimated row count" when "?totalResults=true", otherwise the count is not included.  The default value is "false".

This query parameter defines the where clause. The resource collection will be queried using the provided expressions. The value of this query parameter is one or more expressions. Example: ?q=Deptno>=10 and <= 30;Loc!=NY

Format: ?q=expression1;expression2

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • ActivityTypeCode; string; Code that identifies the activity type.
  • MeasureType; string; Translated name that identifies the measure type. A measure type is a variable whose value is multiplied by an emission factor to obtain the emissions for an emission type.
  • MeasureTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier for the association of a measure type with an activity type. For example, the measure type for stationary combustion could be fuel quantity.
  • MeasureTypeCode; string; Code identifying a measure type.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • AltKey Intended for internal use only.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
    • MeasureTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
  • PrimaryKey Finds the measure type association for an activity type using the specified primary key.
    Finder Variables
    • MeasureTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier of a measure type association for an activity type.

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

This parameter restricts the number of resources returned inside the resource collection. If the limit exceeds the resource count then the framework will only return the available resources.
Used to define the starting position of the resource collection. If offset exceeds the resource count then no resources are returned. Default value is 0.
The resource collection representation will include the "estimated row count" when "?totalResults=true", otherwise the count is not included.  The default value is "false".

Format: ?q=expression1;expression2

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • ActivityTypeCode; string; Code that identifies the activity type.
  • EmissionType; string; Translated name that identifies the emission type, which is a substance such as a greenhouse gas or an air pollutant that's emitted when processes such as fossil fuel combustion or chemical reactions occur.
  • EmissionTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier for the association of an emission type with an activity type.
  • EmissionTypeCode; string; Code identifying an emission type.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • AltKey Intended for internal use only.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
    • EmissionTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
  • PrimaryKey Finds the emission type association for an activity type using the specified primary key.
    Finder Variables
    • EmissionTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier of the emission type association for an activity type.

Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>

For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

description.content: When this parameter is provided, the specified children are included in the resource payload (instead of just a link). The value of this query parameter is "all" or "". More than one child can be specified using comma as a separator. Example: ?expand=Employees,Localizations. Nested children can also be provided following the format "Child.NestedChild" (Example: ?expand=Employees.Managers). If a nested child is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?expand=Employees.Managers" is the same as "?expand=Employees,Employees.Managers" (which will expand Employees and Managers).

This parameter filters the resource fields. Only the specified fields are returned, which means that if no fields are specified, no fields are returned (useful to get only the links). If an indirect child resource is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?fields=Employees.Managers:Empname" is the same as "?fields=;Employees:;Employees.Managers:Empname" (which will only return the "Empname" field for Managers). the value of this query parameter is a list of resource fields. The attribute can be a direct (Example: Employees) or indirect (Example: Employees.Managers) child. It cannot be combined with expand query parameter. If both are provided, only fields will be considered.

Format: ?fields=Attribute1,Attribute2

Format for fields in child resource: ?fields=Accessor1:Attribute1,Attribute2
The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:

This parameter restricts the number of resources returned inside the resource collection. If the limit exceeds the resource count then the framework will only return the available resources.
Used to define the starting position of the resource collection. If offset exceeds the resource count then no resources are returned. Default value is 0.
The resource collection representation will include the "estimated row count" when "?totalResults=true", otherwise the count is not included.  The default value is "false".

This query parameter defines the where clause. The resource collection will be queried using the provided expressions. The value of this query parameter is one or more expressions. Example: ?q=Deptno>=10 and <= 30;Loc!=NY

Format: ?q=expression1;expression2

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • ActivityTypeCode; string; Code that identifies the activity type.
  • EmissionType; string; Translated name that identifies the emission type, which is a substance such as a greenhouse gas or an air pollutant that's emitted when processes such as fossil fuel combustion or chemical reactions occur.
  • EmissionTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier for the association of an emission type with an activity type.
  • EmissionTypeCode; string; Code identifying an emission type.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • AltKey Intended for internal use only.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
    • EmissionTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
  • PrimaryKey Finds the emission type association for an activity type using the specified primary key.
    Finder Variables
    • EmissionTypeAssocId; integer; Unique identifier of the emission type association for an activity type.

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • ActivityTypeCode; string; Code that identifies the activity type.
  • ActivityTypeId; integer; Unique identifier of an activity type that causes a sustainability impact.
  • ActivityTypeName; string; Translated name that identifies the activity type. For example, stationary combustion , mobile combustion, purchased electricity, and purchased goods and services.
  • CreatedBy; string; User who created the record.
  • CreationDate; string; Date and time when the record was created.
  • Description; string; Description of the type of activity.
  • EndDate; string; Date till when an activity type stays valid.
  • InUseFlag; boolean; Identifies if the activity type is used in any activity emissions or emission factor mappings.
  • LastUpdateDate; string; Date and time when the record was last updated.
  • LastUpdatedBy; string; User login by whom the record was last updated.
  • Scope; string; Scope of emissions as defined by the Greenhouse Gas Protocol, that's, Scope 1, Scope 2 Location-based, Scope 2 Market-based or Scope 3.
  • ScopeCategory; string; Category to which scope 3 events, purchase, or activity belongs.
  • ScopeCategoryCode; string; Code that identifies a Scope 3 category.
  • ScopeCode; string; Code that identifies a scope.
  • StartDate; string; Date from when an activity type becomes valid.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • ActivityTypeCodeAltKey Intended for internal use only.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeCode; string; Intended for internal use only.
  • ByActivityTypeCodeFinder Finds the activity type for the specified primary key.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeCode; string; Unique identifier of the activity type.
  • PrimaryKey Finds the activity type for the specified primary key.
    Finder Variables
    • ActivityTypeId; integer; Unique identifier of the activity type.

The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

Contains one of the following values: true or false. If true, the server performs an Upsert operation instead of a Create operation. During an Upsert operation, the server attempts to find an existing resource that matches the payload. If a match is found, the server updates the existing resource instead of creating a new one. If not found or false (default), the server performs a Create operation. Note that the Upsert operation isn't supported for date-effective REST resources.
